J. T. Salvesen & Co. Carl @ Sandarne,—582 pcs. timber, 968 pcs. props, J. T. Salvesen & Co. Order. Montrose @ Drammen,—5,607 props, Order. Amalie @ Christiania,—10,437 props, J. T. Salvesen & Co. Order. Betty @ Fredrikstad,—366,540 staves, A. & S. Paterson. Johanne @ Drammen,—4,808 battens, Hutcheson Bros. Haabet Aukin @ Sundswall,—590 pcs. timber, 1,049 deals, J. T. Salvesen & Co. Order. GREENOCK.
July 16. City of Montreal @ Quebec,—143 pcs. red pine, 34 pcs. balm of Gilead, 549 pcs. square white pine, 324 pcs. birch, 366 pcs. waney board pine, 1,111 pine deals, 2,400 staves, 7,200 wood staves, Singleton, Dunn & Co.
July 17. Dagmar @ Quebec,—50 pcs. elm, 130 pcs. birch, 1,042 deals, 82 ends, 804 pipe staves, 194 std. W.I. staves, 10 cords lathwood, Order.
July 23. Stella @ Skutskar,—77½ doz. battens, 35,032 doz. palings, Abram Lyle & Sons.
July 27. Marion @ Quebec, 4 pcs. white wood, 395 pcs. red pine, 131 pcs. waney white pine, 146 pcs. square white pine, 1,799 deals, 3,600 W.O. W.I. staves, 1,580 pipe staves, 296 pcs. birch, Allison, Cousland & Hamilton. Cambridge @ Quebec,—188 pcs. oak, 93 pcs. elm, 10 pcs. ash, 887 pcs. white pine, 1,600 deals, 2,549 pipe staves, 13,331 W.I. staves, Edmiston & Mitchell.
July 28. Magala @ Dalhousie, N.B.,—92 pcs. spruce timber, 1,515 scantlings, 12,289 deals, 1,561 pine deal ends, 880 spruce deal ends, Wright & Breakuridge.
Aug. 2. Colonial Empire @ Sundswall,—604 pcs. square timber, 1,515 pcs. spruce spars, 145½ fms. firewood, Order.
PORT-GLASGOW.
July 29. Maxwell @ Quebec,—46 pcs. oak, 134 pcs. elm, 23 pcs. ash, 50 pcs. birch, 11 pcs. hickory, 193 pcs. red pine, 865 pcs. white wood, 1,074 pine deals, 987 pipe staves, 14,400 W.O.W.I. staves, 3 cords hemlock lathwood, Hunter, Sheriff & Co.
DISASTROUS FIRE AT HEREFORD.—On Wednesday, the 28th ult., a fire broke out in the timber-yard of Mr. Edward Bowers, at Hereford. The entire stock of wood, both manufactured and unmanufactured, was destroyed, and the whole of the machinery, including a 30-horse power steam engine, was completely ruined. About £600 worth of wood had been brought in a few days previously, and all the materials for the completion of two large contracts were also in readiness for immediate removal. About 100 men are thereby thrown out of employment, and their tools destroyed. The damage is estimated at from £7,000 to £9,000, which loss, we regret to add, is totally unprovided for by insurance. Great sympathy is expressed for Mr. Bowers by his fellow-citizens, and already a public subscription is on foot.
